body:
> I'm not sure how you mean that this is general, because, yes it is general because all other data stores which support data types already have their own mechanism for detecting column types, but they're all implemented in different manners, because each data store provides a different manner to get the data types. For all these data stores it's default behavior to determine the column types, so why not for Excel too?

Maybe just some "column type detector" reusable class that you could use as a sort of builder to add data type observations to. Basically just components that we could  derive a general pattern from. And potentially have the `1000` constant in here incapsulated  (and eventually made parameterized) from etc.
That thing could conceivably then also detect whether something is nullable etc.

> 
> 
> > I'm not sure how you mean that this is general, because, yes it is general because all other data stores which support data types already have their own mechanism for detecting column types, but they're all implemented in different manners, because each data store provides a different manner to get the data types. For all these data stores it's default behavior to determine the column types, so why not for Excel too?
> 
> Maybe just some "column type detector" reusable class that you could use as a sort of builder to add data type observations to. Basically just components that we could derive a general pattern from. And potentially have the `1000` constant in here incapsulated (and eventually made parameterized) from etc.

I see what you mean now. I think the code here can be organized in a manner so that the column type detection is implemented on a separate class. I personally don't think it should be generalized right away in the context of this PR, but more likely in a separate PR, because I'm afraid otherwise the scope of this PR will become a bit too broad.

> I see what you mean now. I think the code here can be organized in a manner so that the column type detection is implemented on a separate class. I personally don't think it should be generalized right away in the context of this PR, but more likely in a separate PR, because I'm afraid otherwise the scope of this PR will become a bit too broad.

Yes that's a fine approach.

>  I'm also not sure if scanning a 1000 rows in an Excel file may be too much, because of possible performance issues.

Maybe we can take a percentage of the file row count? Like check 10% with a max cap of 1000 rows.

> Maybe we can take a percentage of the file row count? Like check 10% with a max cap of 1000 rows.

I don't think it's a case where _we_ can set a default that our users will be happy with. I think 1000 is an OK default for _when the feature is enabled_. I think you should add the number into `ExcelConfiguration` along with a boolean that enables/disables the feature. And the default should be to have it OFF so that we retain backwards compatibility.
LGTM. Again, not an ES 7.x expert, but I guess we're at lazy concensus time now. Do you want it merged @arjansh ?

Hi @kaspersorensen, I asked @jhorcicka if he can also look at this PR, even though he's not a committer on MetaModel, but he's been implementing some code last weeks which uses Elasticsearch 7.3.1, so he may have some useful feedback. I'd like to wait for that first.

While using this branch, I get the following NPE: 

```
ERROR 16:30:26 ElasticSearchRestDataContext - Unexpected error during detectTable for document type '_doc'
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at org.apache.metamodel.elasticsearch.common.ElasticSearchMetaDataParser.parse(ElasticSearchMetaDataParser.java:41)
	at org.apache.metamodel.elasticsearch.rest.ElasticSearchRestDataContext.detectTable(ElasticSearchRestDataContext.java:187)
	at org.apache.metamodel.elasticsearch.rest.ElasticSearchRestDataContext.detectSchema(ElasticSearchRestDataContext.java:155)
	at org.apache.metamodel.elasticsearch.rest.ElasticSearchRestDataContext.<init>(ElasticSearchRestDataContext.java:111)
	at org.apache.metamodel.elasticsearch.rest.ElasticSearchRestDataContext.<init>(ElasticSearchRestDataContext.java:124)
	at org.datacleaner.extension.elasticsearch.MockElasticSearchDatastore.createDatastoreConnection(MockElasticSearchDatastore.java:28)
	at org.datacleaner.connection.UsageAwareDatastore.getDatastoreConnection(UsageAwareDatastore.java:97)
	at org.datacleaner.connection.UsageAwareDatastore.openConnection(UsageAwareDatastore.java:108)
	at org.datacleaner.connection.ElasticSearchDatastore.openConnection(ElasticSearchDatastore.java:183)
	at org.datacleaner.extension.elasticsearch.ElasticSearchIndexAnalyzer.init(ElasticSearchIndexAnalyzer.java:100)
```

It would be nice to fix it here. Add a null check for "metaDataInfo". 

![01](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13213915/66296259-6f143800-e8ed-11e9-9f22-dadfc53bf3ed.png)
All my points were addressed.
Outside of the comments the (Excel) tests currently fail, that should be addressed.

> Outside of the comments the (Excel) tests currently fail, that should be addressed.

I see indeed that I still had one change staged which wasn't commited (validateColumnType vs detectColumnType)
Will be fixed in the next commit

When doing lots of updates (more than 500) in a short period of time (less than 60 seconds), Elasticsearch will fail with this message: "Trying to create too many scroll contexts. Must be less than or equal to: [500]". This is caused by the fact that in the DeleteAndInsertBuilder#getRowsToUpdate() method a DataSet is created, which is converted to a List of rows, which is returned by the method, but the DataSet isn't closed, as a result of which, in case of Elasticsearch, the scroll request for the DataSet isn't cleared and will stay alive for 60 seconds.

I want to address this problem within this pull request.
If its a separate problem from the upgrade, and this has already been reviewed, wouldn't a separate issue and PR be better?

That's a thought that I was having too, but I also have to fix a little bug in the AbstractElasticSearchDataSet#close() method, which is also involved, because the logic which detects if it should actually close the DataSet isn't implemented in the right manner (so right now it doesn't actually close it when the close method is invoked). And I want to add a few tests to demonstrate the issue.

But you maybe right and it maybe better to do that in a separate PR, but then this one preferably should be merged first.
Hmm, I don't even think this one actually has to be merged before. I'm gonna try it on master branch with Elasticsearch 5.6.3 too.

Hmm, if I would fix it based on master I would probably afterwards have to refactor the unit tests I create for it to work with Elasticsearch 7.3.1, so preferably I would implement it based on this branch.
It's not a huge thing in any case, so if it's much easier to just close the scroll context here, it makes sense.
Okay, I'll stick to my original plan then and fix it within the context if this PR.

@SociopathicPixel Can you also add a unit test for an .xlsx Excel file, because MetaModel uses the `XlsxSpreadsheetReaderDelegate` to read these Excel files (see line 192 in `ExcelDataContext`), so you may need to build in a check which ensure that in case `detectColumnTypes` is set to true on the `ExcelConfiguration`, the `DefaultSpreadsheetReaderDelegate` is always used for reading the Excel file.

@SociopathicPixel The values in a Row of an Excel DataSet are all still `String` objects. They don't use the detected column type to return an object of the expected type. This is implemented in the ExcelUtils#createRow(Workbook, Row, DataSetHeader) method.
@kaspersorensen , @LosD Is it possible that one of you takes another look at this PR and merges it if it is passes review?

@arjansh I can take a look tonight, but... What's going on with the builds? All builds are dead, but none of them seem related to this. 2 are Neo4J, one is missing dependencies and one has a broken Java installer. :open_mouth:
@losd See my other PR (https://github.com/apache/metamodel/pull/231) for the Travis build problem.

@arjan Ah, I'm blind. I'll merge that one first, ~then rerun this one~ :)

Edit: Ah man, I can't rerun without pushing something.
@losd If you merge the other one, then I can merge "master" into this PR's branch, which should trigger a new build.
@arjan Sure, I just can't do it until I'm home tonight.
@LosD No need to hurry.
:wave: I'm another @arjan ;-)
I'll fix part of it, and skip for the other, but two issues with this PR: Missing a corresponding issue tracker issue, and there's no CHANGES.md update.

I'm merging the other issue momentarily, but please fix these two issues as you're merging master:
- Missing a corresponding issue tracker issue
- There's no CHANGES.md update
@losd It's a bit late for me now, I'll do that tomorrow morning.
Sure :)
Merged
@SociopathicPixel It may also be a good idea to merge master branch (from apache/metamodel) into this branch, because that contains a general fix for the failing unit tests.

A few comments, but nothing serious. Of course, as I wrote, it's been a long time since I used Java, and it's been an even longer time since I played with ES, so I can't promise that I didn't miss anything.
LGTM, merging! :)
Seems to create a conflict with the Neo4j build.

OK, I won't notify you again about this release, but will get in touch when a new version is available.

If you change your mind, just re-open this PR and I'll resolve any conflicts on it.

> 
> 
> Really appreciate the backwards-compatible approach used here, and the fact that all existing tests are unaltered. My only nitpick is that there are some indentation differences in some of the files. For example `ExcelConfiguration`. But it does also look like the source files have inconsistent indentation so I can live with it, just a note for us that it looks like we need to reformat some files.

Yeah, I didn't apply any formatting on purpose, because then I usually have to undo a lot of changes it makes on code that I did not tough. I can try to apply that now.
I also think that this project's code in general really needs refactoring, because the current is hard to understand and messy right now. That should probably be done in another PR.
LGTM!

@kaspersorensen If this looks good to you, shouldn't we/one of us merge it then? Also should I spent some time to see if I can fix https://github.com/apache/metamodel/pull/233, so we can merge that one too?
@GerardDellemann Can you also update the CHANGES.md file (in the root folder of the MetaModel project), by adding METAMODEL-82?

> 
> 
> @GerardDellemann Can you also update the CHANGES.md file (in the root folder of the MetaModel project), by adding METAMODEL-82?

yeah forgot that, it's done
Hey @arjansh yes I'm glad you merged it. Just thought it would be a bit quick for me to merge it  so shortly after it was posted.
Nice update @arjansh ! Looks good to me.
Looks good to me!
@kaspersorensen Since you approve, can you maybe also merge the pull request? Also, is it a good idea if I initiate a new release of MetaModel after that?

@arjansh yes, sorry I forgot about it but initially just wanted to give time for anyone else to check it too :-)

Yes I think it's a good time to make a release!
Good one! Thanks.
Updated as per PR review remarks

As mentioned in the JIRA comment, let me know if there is too much duplication between the typing package and naming package.
Also, do we need to handle trying to update the datastore with a data type that is different than the one you configured? I haven't tested but it seems to me you can now make a write to csv data stores that you can't read back (unless you reconfigured the datacontext to use string types which will always work)
@kaspersorensen You had some comments on this pull requests, which mark it with "changes requested". Have these been addressed? If so, can we merge the pull request?
Sorry guys @LiveSatomi  @arjansh , had been buried in work for a bit. Gave this my approval now :-)
Reviewed, LGTM.
All my comments have been addressed. @kaspersorensen Can you give it a second look, so that if you approve too, we can merge it?
That's a strange build failure. Is there a way to retrigger it and try again?

@tkingsbury42 The easiest way to trigger the build is by pushing a new change. E.g. add one whitespace in a comment and then push the change.

But I noticed the MetaModel build on Travis has been "unstable" lately, it fails for different kind of random reasons for a few pull requests I was working on. If I have some spare time, I'll see if I can find out what causes that.
We should probably fix the `IN` operator also then. It's using a termsQuery, too.

> We should probably fix the `IN` operator also then. It's using a termsQuery, too.

Actually, DIFFERENT_FROM also does (did) not work. I changed that too.

> The code looks good now. One more thing, can you add the issue that's fixed by this Pull Request to the CHANGES.md in the root folder?

Yes, sure, I keep forgetting to do that.
@kaspersorensen Can you maybe look at my reply to your comment? And if it satisfies you maybe merge this Pull Request?

LGTM. I restarted the failed Travis job.

PS: No reason to @mention any particular contributor like you did here. We want the community to respond, not any particular individual.

> LGTM. I restarted the failed Travis job.
> 
> PS: No reason to @mention any particular contributor like you did here. We want the community to respond, not any particular individual.

Ok, I will delete the specific @.

@kaspersorensen Can you maybe give this pull request another look. It should make the build more stable so we don't get failing unit tests in all pull requests which are unrelated to these pull requests.
Thanks for the nudge Arjan! Yes this looks good to me then!

> Can you merge master into this branch and see if Travis then builds successfully?

I did, now it fails with oracle jdk8 only, in Excel module. This seems unrelated.

![01](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13213915/111438598-bc145480-8704-11eb-847b-a7ffa0b3f040.png)

@jhorcicka We forgot to add the last merged PRs related issues to the CHANGES.md, so maybe in the context of this PR, you can also add this to the CHANGES.md:

```
### Apache MetaModel [WIP]

 * [METAMODEL-1236] - Elasticsearch: not/empty and is/not null do not work for text based columns
 * [METAMODEL-1235] - Elasticsearch: "String index out of range" when schema name and column name are equal
 * [METAMODEL-1232] - Improve stability of Travis CI builds

```
Nice little improvement. Looks good to me.
